sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Introduction
content: JavaScript has a set of primitive data types that are not objects and have no methods. These types represent single values and are immutable.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Number
content: The Number type is used for both integer and floating-point numbers.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ String
content: The String type represents textual data and is enclosed in single, double, or backtick quotes.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Boolean
content: The Boolean type can only be true or false. It is typically used in conditional statements.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Undefined
content: A variable that has been declared but not assigned a value is of type undefined.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Null
content: Null is a special keyword that represents an intentional absence of any object value.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Symbol (ES6)
content: Symbol is a unique and immutable data type introduced in ES6, often used to create unique object property keys.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ BigInt (ES2020)
content: BigInt is used to represent integers larger than the Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Summary
sections.description: Here's a quick summary of all primitive data types in JavaScript:
content: Number: Represents numeric values, both integers and floats.
Undefined: A variable that has been declared but not assigned a value.
Symbol: Unique and immutable identifier (used for object properties).
